choices.text: The cochlear implant electrode stimulates the cochlear nerve endings
The multichannel implant gives better outcome for the patient
Mondini's dysplasia of cochlea is a contraindication of Cochlear implant surgery
Veria technique is the transcanal approach for cochlear implant surgery

questions.text: All of the following are true about cochlear implant surgery except
questions.solution: Mondini dysplasia is a congenital malformation of the inner ear.It helps in being able to detect and recognize a variety of environmental sounds that would previously have been inaudible. Along with the reported improvement in quality of life, Mondini dysplasia is not a contra-indication for multichannel cochlear implantation.

choices.text: It has surgically implantable titanium fixture
It transmits sound directly to cochlea through the bone conduction using the principle of osseointegration
It is not indicated in patients with chronic discharging ear
It is indicated in atresia of external auditory canal

questions.text: All of the following are true about bone anchored hearing aid except
questions.solution:
Bone-anchored hearing aid is a type of hearing aid which is based on the principle of bone conduction. It is primarily suited to people who have conductive hearing loss, unilateral hearing loss and those with mixed hearing loss who cannot otherwise wear 'in the ear' or 'behind the ear' hearing aids. BAHA has three components: (i) titanium fixture (ii) titanium abutment and (iii) sound processor

It is indicated when air-conduction (AC) hearing aid cannot be used:

a.Canal atresia, congenital or acquired, not amenable to treatment.

b.Chronic ear discharge, not amenable to treatment.

c.Excessive feedback and discomfort from air-conduction hearing aid.

choices.text: Korner septum is remnant of petrosquamous suture
Subiculum is a bony spicule which separates oval and round windows
Facial recess is the surgical landmark of posterior tympanotomy
Canal for tendon of Tensor tympani lies on the posterior wall of middle ear

questions.text: Not a true match about the anatomical aspects of ear
questions.solution:
The anterior wall has a thin plate of bone, which separates the cavity from the internal carotid artery. It also has two openings; the lower one for the eustachian tube and the upper one for the canal of tensor tympani muscle.

The posterior wall lies close to the mastoid air cells. It presents a bony projection called pyramid through the summit of which appears the tendon of the stapedius muscle to get attachment to the neck of stapes. Aditus, an opening through which the attic communicates with the antrum, lies above the pyramid. Facial nerve runs in the posterior wall just behind the pyramid. Facial recess or the posterior sinus is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of VIIth nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani and above, by the fossa incudis. Surgically, facial recess is important, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing posterior canal wall

choices.text: Low frequency sensorineural hearing loss in early stages

questions.text: One of the following is not true about meniere's disease
questions.solution: Ménière's disease is distension of the endolymphatic system due to increased volume of endolymph. This can result either from increased production of endolymph or its faulty absorption or both.Usually, disease is unilateral but the other ear may be affected after a few years. Cardinal symptoms of Ménière's disease are (i) episodic vertigo, (ii) fluctuating hearing loss, (iii) tinnitus and (iv) sense of fullness or pressure in the involved ear.

questions.text: Identify the audiological investigation whose recordings are shown in the given picture
questions.solution: Also called BAER or BAEP (brainstem auditory evoked response or potential) or BERA (brainstem evoked response audiometry) is to elicit brainstem responses to auditory stimulation by clicks or tone bursts. It is a noninvasive technique to find the integrity of central auditory pathways through the VIIIth nerve, pons and midbrain. In this method, electrical potentials are generated in response to several click stimuli or tone bursts and picked up from the vertex by surface electrodes. It measures hearing sensitivity in the range of 1000-4000 Hz.

questions.text: All of the following cause referred otalgia through Glossopharyngeal nerve except
questions.solution: Carcinoma of the hypopharynx is very common in India. Practically, most of the tumors are squamous cell types with various grades of differentiation. Symptoms of hypopharyngeal cancer include dysphagia, chronic sore throat, and foreign body sensation in the throat and referred otalgia. Here it is a pain referred to the ear via the Arnold nerve, a division of the 10th cranial nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following is a canal wall up (CWU) otological procedure
questions.solution:
Canal wall down (CWD) and canal wall up (CWU) are the surgical techniques used in the treatment of cholesteatoma. These techniques are mainly distinguished by preservation of the external ear canal.

Canal wall up procedures are advised only in selected cases. In combined approach or intact canal wall mastoidectomy, disease is removed both permeatally, and through cortical mastoidectomy and posterior tympanotomy approach, in which a window is created between the mastoid and middle ear, through the facial recess, to reach sinus tympani

questions.text: A patient of Bell's palsy shows no improvement with 3 weeks of steroid therapy. His electroneuronography reveals facial nerve degeneration to the extent of more than 90 percent. What should be the next step in the management
questions.solution:
In electromyography, the facial nerve is stimulated at the stylomastoid foramen and the compound muscle action potentials are picked up by the surface electrodes. Supramaximal stimulation is used to obtain maximal action potentials. The responses of action potentials of the paralyzed side are compared with that of the normal side on similar stimulation and thus the percentage of degenerating fibers is calculated. Studies reveal that degeneration of 90% occurring in the first 14 days indicates poor recovery of function.

Nerve decompression relieves pressure on the nerve fibers and thus improves the microcirculation of the nerve. Vertical and tympanic segments of nerve are decompressed.

questions.text: Which is not found on the medial wall of middle ear
questions.solution:
The posterior wall lies close to the mastoid air cells. It presents a bony projection called pyramid through the summit of which appears the tendon of the stapedius muscle to get attachment to the neck of stapes.

The medial wall is formed by the labyrinth. It presents a bulge called promontory which is due to the basal coil of cochlea; oval window into which is fixed the footplate of stapes; round window or the fenestra cochleae which is covered by the secondary tympanic membrane. Above the oval window is the canal for facial nerves. Its bony covering may sometimes be congenitally dehiscent and the nerve may lie exposed making it very vulnerable to injuries or infection. Above the canal for the facial nerve is the prominence of the lateral semicircular canal. Just anterior to the oval window, the medial wall presents a hook-like projection called processus cochleariformis. The tendon of tensor tympani takes a turn here to get attachment to the neck of malleus. The cochleariform process also marks the level of the first genu of the facial nerve which is an important landmark for surgery of the facial nerve. Medial to the pyramid is a deep recess called sinus tympani, which is bounded by the subiculum below and the ponticulus above.

questions.text: All are clinically applicable statements to glomus Jugulare except
questions.solution:
It is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.It is most common in middle age(40 to 50 years) females rather than males.

Glomus jugulare arise from the dome of the jugular bulb, invade the hypotympanum and jugular foramen, causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement. The erosion of the carotico-jugular spine bone is called the Phelps sign.

Earliest symptoms are hearing loss and tinnitus. Hearing loss is conductive and slowly progressive. Tinnitus is pulsatile and of swishing character, synchronous with pulse

10% of the tumors are familial, 10% multicentric (occurring in more than one site) and up to 10% functional, i.e. they secrete catecholamines.

choices.text: Semont maneuver is done to treat this condition
Otoconia most commonly migrate to lateral semicircular canal to cause this entity
There is no hearing loss in this condition
Dix Hallpike maneuver shows rotational geotropic nystagmus

questions.text: All are true about benign paroxysmal positional vertigo except
questions.solution: It is characterized by vertigo when the head is placed in a certain critical position. There is no hearing loss or other neurologic symptoms. Positional testing establishes the diagnosis and helps to differentiate it from positional vertigo of central origin. When otoconia settles on the cupula of the posterior semicircular canal in a critical head position, it causes displacement of the cupula and vertigo.

choices.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential is a useful investigation

questions.text: All are characteristic features of superior semicircular canal dehiscence except
questions.solution: Superior canal dehiscence syndrome (SCDS) is caused by an abnormal opening between the uppermost semicircular canal in the upper part of the inner ear and the brain. Typically, SCD causes a low frequency conductive loss. Most often, the conductive loss is mild, and in the low frequencies only

questions.text: A 5 year old patient presents with the history of hearing loss. On examination he is found to have a pearly white mass behind the intact tympanic membrane. What is the most possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Congenital cholesteatoma arises from the embryonic epidermal cell resting in the middle ear cleft or temporal bone. Congenital cholesteatoma occurs at three important sites: middle ear, petrous apex and the cerebellopontine angle, and produces symptomatology depending on its location.

Essentially, cholesteatoma consists of two parts: (i) the matrix, which is made up of keratinizing squamous epithelium resting on a thin stroma of fibrous tissues and (ii) a central white mass, consisting of keratin debris produced by the matrix

questions.text: A patient of head injury has bluish discolouration over the mastoid area, bleeding from EAC and complaining of hearing loss with normal facial nerve function. After three days, the patient starts having facial weakness. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution: Temporal bone fracture is suggested by Battle sign (postauricular ecchymosis) and bleeding from the external auditory canal. As the fracture can sometimes involve the ossicles,inner ear and facial nerve, symptoms such as hearing loss, vertigo, balance disturbance, or facial paralysis may be present.

questions.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) tests which nerve
questions.solution: Vestibular evoked myogenic potentials (VEMPs) are used to test the otolith organs in patients with vertigo and imbalance.The vestibular-evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) is a short-latency potential evoked through activation of vestibular receptors using sound or vibration.The vestibular evoked myogenic potential reflex is produced by the inferior vestibular nerve, which provides evidence of the integrity of the vestibular response.

questions.text: A patient of left sided Meniere's disease does not respond to conventional medical treatment. His episodes are becoming more frequent and he has developed severe sensorineural hearing loss on left side. Which is the best further treatment for this patient?
questions.solution: It is a small wick made of polyvinyl acetate and measures 1 mm × 9 mm. It is meant to deliver drugs from the external canal to the inner ear and thus avoid repeated intratympanic injections. It has been used to deliver steroids in sudden deafness and gentamicin to destroy vestibular labyrinths in Meniere's disease.

choices.text: Extra temporal part of facial nerve

questions.text: In a patient of facial nerve injury-Schirmer's test shows normal lacrimation, taste sensation is impaired and stapedial reflex is present. Where is the level of injury?
questions.solution: Schirmer's test compares the lacrimation of the two sides. A strip of filter paper is hooked in the lower fornix of each eye and the amount of wetting of the strip is measured. Decreased lacrimation indicates lesion proximal to the geniculate ganglion as the secretomotor fibers to lacrimal gland leave at the geniculate ganglion via greater superficial petrosal nerve.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from bilateral adductor spasmodic dysphonia. What type of voice is expected in this patient?
questions.solution: The adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to go into adduction. Voice becomes strained or strangled, and phonation is interrupted in between leading to voice breaks. Larynx is however morphologically normal. Severity of the condition differs from mild and intermittent symptoms to those with moderate or severe dysphonia. Flexible fiberoptic laryngoscopy is useful during which a patient's speech, sustained phonation and respiratory activities are studied. Patient may have tremors of larynx, palate and pharynx

questions.text:
A 3 month old child has developed persistent dyspnoea and stridor after an episode of upper respiratory infection. The cry of the baby is normal. On CT scan of the neck, the subglottic diameter has been found to be 2.5 mm. He did not show any improvement in the next 6 months. Subsequently, the child has been operated for airway surgery and a silicon device has been placed in the airway.

What is the name of this device?
questions.solution: The Montgomery T-tube is a device used as a combined tracheal stent and an airway after laryngotracheal surgery.The tube is inserted into the upper trachea or larynx following trauma or surgery to serve as a means to maintain the tracheal airway as well as serving as a stent.

questions.text: A 6 year old child develops sudden respiratory distress and stridor without any other pre-existing illness. On endoscopy of larynx, the both vocal cords are found to be in paramedian position and are immobile. All constitute part of treatment except-
questions.solution: Type 1 thyroplasty (medialization thyroplasty) It is the most commonly used surgical procedure to correct unilateral vocal cord paralysis by medialization of the vocal cord.

choices.text: Argon and KTP laser are visible lasers where as CO2 laser and Nd YAG lasers are invisible
Silicon Endotracheal tube wrapped with metallic foil should be used for laser assisted laryngeal surgeries
CO2 laser can pass through the flexible endoscopes

questions.text: All of the following are true about lasers in ENT except
questions.solution: CO2 Laser: Wavelength 10,400 nm, invisible, requires an aiming beam of helium-neon laser, cannot pass through flexible optical fibers, and requires articulated arm with a series of reflective mirrors to direct the beam to the target area. Requires a micromanipulator if working through an operating microscope, can be absorbed by water or clear glass. Ordinary glass or lenses of the microscope can also absorb the rays as well as the glasses worn by the operator. It is absorbed by tissues high in water and is not color dependent. Reflection and scatter through tissues is minimum. It causes minimal effect on adjacent tissues in depth and laterally. CO2 laser is the workhorse laser and has been widely used in ENT. It can cut precisely, coagulate bleeders and vaporize tissues. Clinically it has been used in laryngeal surgery to excise vocal nodules, polyps, cysts, granulomas or juvenile laryngeal papillomas.

choices.text: Allergic mucin with eosinophils and charcot leyden crystals
Homogeneous Nasal Polypi on CT scan

questions.text: All are true about allergic fungal sinusitis except
questions.solution: Allergic fungal sinusitis is an allergic reaction to the causative fungus and presents with sinunasal polyposis and mucin. The latter contains eosinophils, CharcotLeyden crystals and fungal hyphae. There is no invasion of the sinus mucosa with fungus. Usually more than one sinus is involved on one or both sides. CT scan shows mucosal thickening with hyperdense areas. There may be expansion of the sinus or bone erosion due to pressure, but no fungal invasion. Treatment is endoscopic surgical clearance of the sinuses with provision of drainage and ventilation.

choices.text: Weber Fergusson incision is used for total maxillectomy
Nickel exposure leads to squamous cell carcinoma of sinuses
Adenocarcinoma of ethmoid is more common in Furniture industry workers
Tumors of Infrastructure of maxilla carry poor 5 year survival rate

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about malignancy of sinuses except
questions.solution: Survival of maxillary sinus diminishes with the stage of tumor. Overall 5 year survival is about 40-50%

choices.text: Rigid endoscopy of larynx with continuous light
Flexible endoscopy of larynx with blue light
Rigid endoscopy of larynx with flashing light
Flexible endoscopy of larynx with continuous light

questions.text: Video Stroboscopy of larynx is
questions.solution: Videostroboscopy is the most commonly used method to visualize vocal fold vibration and is an essential tool for voice assessment.It uses a flexible or rigid endoscope combined with a microphone and a flashing strobe light.

questions.text: A wide roomy nasal cavity with thick crust formation and disfigured hard external nose is seen in
questions.solution: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Gram Negative bacillus called Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis or Frisch bacillus.The disease passes through three stages-catarrhal, granulomatous and cicatricial. It causes woody infiltration of the upper lip. Other areas involved are larynx (subglottic region) and trachea leading to airway obstruction. Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies are characteristically seen in histology.

choices.text: Ebstein Barr virus is the etiological factor

questions.text: All of the following are common features of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma except
questions.solution: Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma can invade upward and backward through the skull base to the cavernous sinus and middle cranial fossa and invade cranial nerves (CN) II to VI (upper CN palsy).

choices.text: Ponticulus is the bony spicule between oval and round window
Subiculum is the bony spicule from promontory to pyramid
Donaldson's line is surgical landmark for Posterior cranial fossa
Facial recess is the surgical landmark for posterior tympanotomy

questions.text: Which of the following is appropriate statement-
questions.solution: Facial recess or the posterior sinus is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of VIIth nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani and above, by the fossa incudis. Surgically, facial recess is important, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall. Posterior tympanotomy is the avenue to the facial recess of the middle ear from the mastoid antrum.

questions.text: All of the following are ototoxic drugs except
questions.solution: Ototoxicity is when a person develops hearing or balance problems due to a medicine. This can happen when someone is on a high dose of a drug that treats cancer, infections, or other illnesses.

questions.text: CT scan of neck of a patient of carcinoma larynx has been found to have the involvement of epiglottis, left aryepiglottic fold, left arytenoid, left vocal cord with the involvement of pre-epiglottic space. What is the ideal treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Management of T4 laryngeal cancer patients with postoperative radiotherapy after total laryngectomy is generally advised.

Total laryngectomy: The entire larynx including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles and one or more rings of trachea are removed. Pharyngeal wall is repaired and the lower tracheal stump sutured to the skin for breathing.

Total laryngectomy is indicated in the following conditions: (i) T3 lesions (i.e. with cord fixed) (ii) All T4 lesions (iii) Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage (iv) Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement (v) Lesions of posterior commissure (vi) Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery (vii) Transglottic cancers, i.e. tumors involving supraglottis and glottis across the ventricle, causing fixation of the vocal cord. It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis.

Surgical ablation may be combined with pre- or postoperative radiation to decrease the incidence of recurrence.

questions.text:
A 23 year old person suffering from acute frontal sinusitis has developed a painful read forehead swelling.(see the image)
Which of the following is the possible diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Osteomyelitis of frontal bone results from acute infection of frontal sinus either directly or through the venous spread. It can also follow trauma or surgery of frontal sinus in the presence of acute infection. Pus may form externally under the periosteum as soft doughy swelling (Pott's puffy tumor), or internally as an extradural abscess. Treatment consists of large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of frontal sinus through its floor.

questions.text: The given two nasal features are seen in which stage of Syphilis
questions.solution:
Nasal syphilis is of two types: acquired and congenital.

  1. Acquired. It occurs as:

(a) Primary. It manifests as the primary chancre of the vestibule of the nose. It is rare.

(b) Secondary. Rarely recognized. It manifests as simple rhinitis with crusting and fissuring in the nasal vestibule. Diagnosis is suggested by the presence of mucous patches in the pharynx, skin rash, fever and generalized lymphadenitis.

(c) Tertiary. This is the stage in which the nose is commonly involved. Typical manifestation is the formation of a gumma on the nasal septum. Later, the septum is destroyed both in its bony and cartilaginous parts. Perforation may also appear in the hard palate. There is offensive nasal discharge with crusts. Bony or cartilaginous sequestra may be seen. Bridge of the nose collapses causing a saddle nose deformity.

  1. Congenital. It occurs in two forms: early and late.

(a) Early form. It is seen in the first 3 months of life and manifests as 'snuffles.' Soon the nasal discharge becomes purulent. This is associated with fissuring and excoriation of the nasal vestibule and of the upper lip.

(b) Late form. Usually manifests around puberty. Clinical picture is similar to that seen in the tertiary stage of acquired syphilis. Gummatous lesions destroy the nasal structures. Other stigmata of syphilis such as corneal opacities, deafness and Hutchinson's teeth are also present.

questions.text: A 52 year adult patient presenting with right side hearing loss has been subjected to audiological investigations and diagnosed to be a case of right sided serous otitis media. What will be the priority in further management of this patient?
questions.solution: A nasopharyngoscopy is a surgical procedure performed to examine the nose and throat. ... diagnose cases of nasopharyngeal cancer, often in addition to a biopsy

questions.text: A patient with ear wax underwent syringing. During syringing, the patient developed a syncopal episode. Stimulation of which nerve is responsible ?
questions.solution: Mechanical stimulation of the external auditory meatus can activate the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve) and evoke reflex cough or syncope.

questions.text: Blood stained foul smelling chronic ear discharge with otoscopy findings given in the image. What is the probable clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Primary Acquired Cholesteatoma : It is called primary as there is no history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. Theories on its genesis are:

(a) Invagination of pars flaccida. Persistent negative pressure in the attic causes a retraction pocket which accumulates keratin debris. When infected, the keratin mass expands towards the middle ear. Thus, attic perforation is in fact the proximal end of an expanding invaginated sac

(b) Basal cell hyperplasia. There is proliferation of the basal layer of pars flaccida induced by subclinical childhood infections. Expanding cholesteatoma then breaks through pars flaccida forming an attic perforation.

(c) Squamous metaplasia. Normal pavement epithelium of the attic undergoes metaplasia, keratinizing squamous epithelium due to subclinical infections. Such a change has also been demonstrated in cases of otitis media with effusion.

choices.text: Atticoantral CSOM with sigmoid sinus thrombosis

questions.text: Mohan, 22 years old, male gives a history of right sided ear discharge, foul smelling and occasionally blood stains for the last 6 years. For the last 3 days the patient has developed fever with chills, headache and pitting oedema over the mastoid region. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution: Atticoantral. Also called unsafe or dangerous type; it involves the posterosuperior part of the cleft (i.e. attic, antrum and mastoid) and is associated with an attic or a marginal perforation. The disease is often associated with a bone-eroding process such as cholesteatoma, granulations or osteitis. Risk of complications is high in this variety.

questions.text: A patient suffering from chronic recurrent heartburn, epigastric pain has developed a hoarse voice for the last one month. The laryngeal fiberoptic laryngoscopy has revealed the congestion and mamillation of mucosa in the interarytenoid area. What is the possible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Pachydermia laryngis is a rare disorder characterized by thickening of the laryngeal epithelium. It appears as excess, uneven and rough tissue in the space between the arytenoid cartilages. The membranous vocal folds may also become thickened.Symptoms include Hoarse voice cough.,dyspnea,stridor.

Findings include discrete or confluent, flat or papillary, grey-white, irregular patches covering the laryngeal mucosa.

choices.text: Sensory end organ of Utricle and saccule
Sensory end organ of semicircular canals

questions.text: What is Cupula in the inner ear?
questions.solution: The cilia of the sensory hair cells project into the cupula, which is a gelatinous mass extending from the surface of crista to the ceiling of the ampulla and forms a watertight partition, only to be displaced to one or the other side like a swing door, with movements of endolymph. The gelatinous mass of cupula consists of polysaccharide and contains canals into which project the cilia of sensory cells.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication of auditory brainstem implant?
questions.solution: This implant is designed to stimulate the cochlear nuclear complex in the brainstem directly by placing the implant in the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle.An auditory brainstem implant provides hearing to people with hearing loss who can't benefit from a hearing aid or cochlear implant.

questions.text: Which audiological finding is true about Auditory neuropathy
questions.solution: Auditory neuropathy is a rare type of hearing loss. It is caused by disruption of the nerve impulses travelling from the inner ear to the brain. It has Anormal BERA and normal OAE.

choices.text: Epstein-Barr virus is an etiological agent
Bilateral conductive deafness in an adult patient is a common presentation
Cervical lymph node metastasis is seen in 75% patients
Commonest histopathological type is undifferentiated carcinoma

questions.text: All of the following are true about nasopharyngeal carcinoma except
questions.solution: Painless enlargement due to upper cervical lymph node metastases is the most common presenting feature of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
